item.title: Graphics Java
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

A StringBuilder is a good way to do it, especially if you don’t need to pull the text back out (such as for network transfer, editing previous lines, copying lines, etc.) Arrays simplify some other features that you obviously don’t need, but they come at a cost. StringBuilder will be more efficient since you didn’t roll out your own display component, so it’s the better choice here.

Read full topic

@wildskiller wrote:

I’m making a text rpg where you have to type your selections in the box.

1115rmw.jpg1366×768

I did do what you guys told me about the arrays and how I shouldn’t use a map. I am using a string builder for my console input, and a list for my console output. I’m sure someone might tell me that I shouldn’t do that either -.-, but I still like some criticism on how I do things.

Read full topic

item.title: Graphics Java
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

eyeownyew:

I looked into all of the regular swing components, none of them seem to be able to have that appearance. I’ve been just creating my own UI elements using images/rectangles and coding everything myself… I haven’t found anything with Slick that would have what I’m looking for either. Really, I’m just doing everything using Graphics2D with Slick being the interface between my program and Graphics2D. I’m really not using any Slick-specific tools, though I do enjoy the fullscreen options with Slick

That’s why you implement your own look-and-feel (LAF) model to make it look that way.

As far as using Slick, there should be options for UI implementations that use slick. Maybe there’s even an interface that allows Swing to be rendered using Slick, since Slick is designed to replace the Java 2D pipeline and that’s all Swing/AWT use anyway.

Finally, I do not recommend implementing your own UI. You will spend a considerable amount of time implementing something that will not be as good as Swing functionally and possibly even efficiently. Swing is incredibly bloaty, but it’s efficient enough for most applications. Do not implement an UI system unless you can clearly justify that you have no other option. In this case, you do have many other options.

Read full topic

I’m really not using any Slick-specific tools, though I do enjoy the fullscreen options with Slick

htps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W3VQULl1vK8
at 0:20, the bottom left corner. That is very similar to what I ended up having.[/quote]You should be able to do all of that with a JTextArea.

That said, if you are making your own game and need UI components, there’s nothing wrong with creating your own UI system. I’m not sure how far Slick2D goes into that but it should have something about it I would assume?

item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

Must I do this?:

g.setColor(Color.blue); drawString(g, Client.getPlayer().getUsername() + ": ", 10, container.getHeight() - 20); g.setColor(Color.lightGray); drawString(g, toSend + "|", 10 + font.getWidth(Client.getPlayer().getUsername() + ": "), container.getHeight() - 20); g.setClip(0, container.getHeight() - 250, 600, 230); for (int i = 0; i < cbText.size() && i < 50; i++) { drawString( g, cbText.get(i), 10, (container.getHeight() - 42) - (((cbText.size() - i - 1) * lineHeight) + (scrollY * lineHeight))); } g.clearClip(); Image toDraw = scrollbar; yToDraw = (container.getHeight() - 225); if (cbText.size() - 11 >= 1) { scrollbarHeight = (int) (200.0f * ((float) 11 / (float) cbText .size())); toDraw = toDraw.getScaledCopy(20, (int) (200.0f * ((float) 11 / (float) cbText.size()))); yToDraw += 200 - ((int) (200.0f * ((float) 11 / (float) cbText .size()))); } if (scrollY != 0) yToDraw -= (int) (200 * (float) ((float) Math.abs(scrollY) / (float) cbText .size())); g.drawImage(toDraw, 578, yToDraw);
To make my own chatbox (with scrolling, this did end up being entirely functional), or is there some easier way of doing this?

item.description:
@wildskiller wrote:

eyeownyew:

This is somewhat irrelevant (though also somewhat relevant) – is it possible to use a scrollpane for a rectangle you have drawn yourself or must you do all of the code for scrolling through text in the rectangle yourself aswell? I conquered this problem awhile back, was just curious because I’ve never heard of that being a solution (if it is one)

I’ve searched for this already and haven’t found anything on it but what imthenull gave me. I’ve already written working classes like this but I lost my flashdrive with this shit, so I’m trying to re-write it.
[hr]
Alright, I fixed it. This was because I was calling the class twice and the other class was overlapping as null.

Anyway, thanks for the input on what I should do for my code.

item.title: Graphics Java
item.dc:creator: @wildskiller wildskiller
item.description:
@wildskiller wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:6, topic:528570”][quote author=wildskiller link=topic=647324.msg4353466#msg4353466 date=1377051395]

Replace your arraylist and map with normal arrays, and then update the OP with that code. You have no reason to use arraylists or maps here.

I’ll do that, but I want to use the map for when I want to add a scroll bar. The lines for the keys are a necessity.
[/quote]I don’t quite understand? You don’t need a map to use a scroll bar[/quote][quote=“sinisoul, post:7, topic:528570”]Uh, yeah you don’t need a map for that.[/quote]

Why shouldn’t I have a map for the scroll bar for the console? When I scroll up, I want to be able to see the earlier messages that were output to the console. As I scroll up, I will scroll through the map’s line numbers.

I changed the current input to an array, but it still resets when I use it in the paint method.

[code=java]package game.content.graphics;

import game.Game;

import java.awt.Color;
import java.awt.Font;
import java.awt.Graphics;
import java.awt.Graphics2D;
import java.awt.event.KeyEvent;
import java.awt.event.KeyListener;
import java.util.*;

import javax.swing.JPanel;

/**

  • @author Albert Beaupre

  • Written June 20, 2013.

  • This class is used to handle the console’s inputs and outputs.
    */
    public class GameConsole extends JPanel implements KeyListener {

    /**

    • The default serial version uid.
      */
      private static final long serialVersionUID = 1L;

    /**

    • The characters allowed to be entered into the console.
      */
      public static final String ALLOWED_CHARACTERS = “abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyzABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ0123456789”;

    /**

    • The max amount of characters allowed to be input.
      */
      public static final short MAX_CHARACTERS = 30;

    /**

    • This is a map of the output to the console.
    • The Integer is the line number.
    • The String is the input.
      */
      private Map<Integer, String> consoleOutput = new HashMap<Integer, String>();

    /**

    • This is a list of the current input in the input line.
    • The String is the characters put into the input line.
      */
      private String[] currentInput = new String[MAX_CHARACTERS];

    /**

    • The amount of lines in the console.
      */
      private int lines, inputSize;

    public GameConsole() {
    resetInput();
    }

    /**

    • This is used to paint the graphic
    • components to the screen.
    • @param g The graphics.
      */
      public void paint(Graphics g) {
      super.paintComponents(g);
      Graphics2D g2D = (Graphics2D) g;
      g.setFont(new Font(“Serif”, Font.BOLD, 12));
      g.setColor(Color.black);
      g.fillRect(0, 0, Game.WIDTH, Game.HEIGHT);
      g.setColor(Color.white);
      g.drawLine(0, Game.HEIGHT - 65, Game.WIDTH, Game.HEIGHT - 65);
      g.drawString(“wtf”+currentInputString(), 10, Game.HEIGHT - 50);
      for (int i = 0; i < getConsoleOutput().size(); i++) {
      g.drawString(getConsoleOutput().get(i), 10, ((Game.HEIGHT - 75) - (15 * i)));
      }
      repaint();
      }

    public void resetInput() {
    for (int i = 0; i < MAX_CHARACTERS; i++) {
    currentInput[i] = “”;
    }
    inputSize = 0;
    }

    public String currentInputString() {
    StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder("");
    for (int i = 0; i < MAX_CHARACTERS; i++)
    sb.append(currentInput[i]);
    return sb.toString();
    }

    public Map<Integer, String> getConsoleOutput() {
    return consoleOutput;
    }

    public void setConsoleOutput(Map<Integer, String> consoleOutput) {
    this.consoleOutput = consoleOutput;
    }

    /*public List getCurrentInput() {
    return currentInput;
    }

    public void setCurrentInput(List currentInput) {
    this.currentInput = currentInput;
    }*/

    @Override
    public void keyPressed(KeyEvent e) {
    int code = e.getKeyCode();
    String text = KeyEvent.getKeyText(code);
    System.out.println(“Key Pressed [”+code+"]: “+text+” Input: “+currentInputString()+” Lines: "+lines);
    if (code == KeyEvent.VK_ENTER) {
    if (inputSize <= 0) {
    return;
    }
    consoleOutput.put(lines++, currentInputString());
    resetInput();
    return;
    }
    if (code == KeyEvent.VK_BACK_SPACE) {
    if (inputSize > 0)
    currentInput[–inputSize] = “”;
    return;
    }
    if (ALLOWED_CHARACTERS.contains(text)) {
    if (inputSize < MAX_CHARACTERS)
    currentInput[inputSize++] = text;
    }
    }

    @Override
    public void keyReleased(KeyEvent e) {

    }

    @Override
    public void keyTyped(KeyEvent e) {

    }

    public int getLines() {
    return lines;
    }

    public void setLines(int lines) {
    this.lines = lines;
    }

}
[/code]

Doing this works fine

public GameConsole() {
		consoleOutput.put(0, "asdasd");
		currentInput.add("ofdmgf");
	}
